awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Dissecting the whole-brain circuit mechanisms for oxytocinergic control of pain avoidance behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
General Abstract

The experience of pain triggers a host of different physiological and behavioral responses that help an animal minimize the potential for injury and maximize its probability of survival.  Describing how neural circuits respond to painful experience is therefore important for better understanding a crucial aspect of brain function.  To accomplish this goal, this project will examine pain processing in the larval zebrafish, a common laboratory model organism whose brain shares many essential features with that of humans while being small enough to study and manipulate in uniquely powerful ways.  These features will enable this work to investigate how cells that produce the neurotransmitter oxytocin shape the neural representation of and behavioral response to pain, at the level of the entire brain.  Because oxytocin-producing cells are highly conserved and thought to be important in pain processing in all vertebrates, the insight provided by this work will help to create models for neural circuit function that generalize across species.  The work will therefore serve the national interest by advancing our understanding of the fundamental ways that nervous systems process pain, which will not only tell us more about how brains work, in general, but which could also lead to unexpected insights into pain management. Additionally, the use of a simple model organism will enable resources and expertise developed in this work to be easily applied to a variety of planned educational activities at the high school, college, and graduate levels.

Technical Abstract

While oxytocinergic neurons in the vertebrate hypothalamus are best known for their roles in reproduction, learning, and social behavior, an emerging body of evidence shows that OXT is also an important modulator of the pain response.  As with its other functions, OXT's role in pain is integrative, effecting diverse physiological and neuronal events in concert to influence behavior.  While previous work in mammals has emphasized the analgesic and fear-attenuating effects of OXT, the Douglass lab has recently discovered that, in the larval zebrafish, activation of OXT neurons by acute pain is a central event in promoting defensive "flight" behaviors.  The circuit mechanisms behind OXT's role in pain avoidance, the contribution of other neurotransmitters released by the OXT neurons, and the functional architecture of the underlying networks all remain unknown.  The current proposal will use genetic and optogenetic manipulations in combination with whole-brain anatomy, functional imaging, circuit labeling, and behavior, in order to identify the cellular targets of OXT neurons that mediate their effects on pain avoidance and characterize anatomical heterogeneity within the population of OXT neurons with respect to behavioral function.  In parallel, the project leverage its core expertise and resources to create a summer course for high school students in the use of zebrafish as a model organism for neuroscience, and an intensive graduate course in microscopy.

por.por_cntn:
The neurotransmitter oxytocin (OXT) is well known for playing essential roles in social behavior, but has a host of additional functions that include an unexpected contribution to the processing of and behavioral response to pain. In our previous work we found that oxytocin-producing neurons become activated within milliseconds of a noxious stimulus and promote rapid defensive behaviors that help an animal to avoid threats. In this project, we used the larval zebrafish as a model to understand the mechanisms that OXT neurons use to control these behaviors. Like other fish, zebrafish are not thought to experience the same degree of subjective distress that characterizes pain in humans, but as a vertebrate species their brains are highly similar to our own and employ many of the same neural circuits to accomplish their goals. By studying these phenomena in a simplified brain with far fewer neurons than in humans, we hoped to gain a more complete understanding of the connection between OXT neuron activity and behavior.

Using a multifaceted approach involving electrophysiological recordings, behavioral measurements, genetic manipulations, and microscopy, we have made several fundamental discoveries about the role of OXT neurons within the pain defense circuit. First, we identified a population of pre-motor neurons in the brainstem, which directly control the initiation of all forms of swimming behavior, as the functional targets of OXT that allow it to promote pain defense. Second, we showed that OXT neurons alter activity in the pre-motor cell group by simultaneously releasing both OXT itself – as expected – as well as a second neurotransmitter called glutamate. Third, we found that these two cues operate on completely different timescales, with glutamate release driving a defensive behavior within milliseconds of a noxious stimulus, and OXT persisting over a much longer duration to sensitize the motor network well after the painful event. Fourth, we found that the relatively small subset of OXT neurons that interact with the pre-motor network are selectively activated by painful stimuli, while the majority of other cells remain silent. And  fifth, we were able to directly measure OXT release using multiple new techniques and found that it can act in a highly localized way, contrary to accepted models. Our data collectively show that OXT and the neurons that make it use unanticipated and parallel mechanisms to heighten the behavioral response to pain on different timescales, and show that OXT-producing neurons can control their targets within the brain with a high degree of precision. Are data are among the first to explore the functional organization of an OXT-producing brain region in this level of detail, and our findings will be important to researchers interested in OXT, pain, and motor behaviors.

In parallel, we developed training and outreach programs that made a strong positive impact on public understanding of neuroscience as well as on the training of future scientists. At the University of Utah, we developed an intensive course in microscopy for Ph.D. students that emphasized developing a detailed understanding of core optical and analytical techniques, including an emerging set of methods that use deep learning and other forms of artificial intelligence to acquire, enhance, and interpret biological images. Within the greater Salt Lake City community, we worked closely with a local chapter of Mathematics, Engineering, Science, Achievement (MESA) at an alternative high school called The Horizonte Academy to teach students about the big questions in neuroscience, and the ways that researchers go about answering them. Over the duration of this grant, roughly 60 high schoolers participated in a series of lectures and hands-on laboratory exercises to see neuroscience in action. We are now continuing to build on that foundation and are excited to help improve public understanding of and respect for science.
